title: SEC vs. Coinbase
description: A micro-lesson that makes SEC vs. Coinbase usable.

hook.text: In 2023, the SEC sued Coinbase â€” the largest US crypto exchange â€” for listing tokens it considered unregistered securities.

buildup.text: The SEC had approved Coinbase's public listing in 2021. Two years later, it sued the same company for its core business.

discovery.text: Coinbase argued the SEC never provided clear rules. It asked for rulemaking, was denied, and then was sued.

twist.text: Coinbase went on offense, suing the SEC for failing to create clear crypto regulations. A rare counterattack against a regulator.

climax.text: The case highlights the impossible position of crypto companies: follow rules that don't exist yet, or get sued.

punchline.text: The SEC approved Coinbase's IPO, then sued it for doing what the IPO described.

quiz.question: What irony exists in the SEC vs. Coinbase case?
options: Coinbase never operated in the US
The SEC approved Coinbase's IPO then sued it for its disclosed business model
